cc_detail.real_name: Jeff Muizelaar [:jrmuizel] on parental leave until at least June 25

comments.text:
Created attachment 8957113
Screenshot from 2018-03-08 12-27-33.png

Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0
Build ID:20180307220100

[Affected versions]:
Nightly 60.0a1, Firefox Beta 59.0b14

[Affected platforms]:
Ubuntu 16.04 X64, Mac OS X 10.12, Windows 10 x64

[Steps to reproduce]:
1.Launch Nightly 60.0a1 with a new profile
2.Login into https://calendar.google.com

[Expected result]:
The page should be loaded without issues

[Actual result]:
Two black lines are displayed when the page is loaded (please see the attached screenshot)
comments.author: roxana.leitan@softvision.ro

comments.text:
Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:61.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/61.0
Build ID:20180411100123

I reproduced the issue using the latest Nightly 61.0a1 on Ubuntu 16.04 x64, Mac OS X 10.13 and Windows 10 x64.
comments.author: roxana.leitan@softvision.ro

comments.text: Is it possible for you to get a regression window?

comments.text: Is it possible to get an inbound/autoland range?

comments.text:
This is what mozregression displays:

CRITICAL: Last build d11c29c1db3a is missing, but mozregression can't find a build after - so it is excluded, but it could contain the regression!
There are no build artifacts on inbound for these changesets (they are probably too old).
comments.author: roxana.leitan@softvision.ro

comments.text: I guess someone needs to do builds for this range to narrow it down.
